Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. No
substantial violations were found.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

II. ALLEGATION(S)
Violation
Established?
Youth died from drowning at the home of a licensed foster No
placement. It is unknown at this time if pool safety policies were
reviewed or adhered to.
Additional Findings No
III. METHODOLOGY
08/02/2021 Special Investigation Intake
2021C0444002
08/02/2021 Special Investigation Initiated - Letter
08/02/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emailed MDHHS FC worker to advise I was assigned DCWL
complaint
08/02/2021 Contact - Document Sent
Emailed MDHHS Program Manager to set up onsite visit
08/02/2021 Contact - Document Sent

08/04/2021 Contact - Face to Face

08/04/2021 Contact - Face to Face
Interviewed MDHHS Licensing Supervisor
08/04/2021 Contact - Face to Face

08/04/2021 Contact - Face to Face

08/16/2021 Exit Conference
Discussed findings with Director and Program Manager.
ALLEGATION:
Youth died from drowning at the home of a licensed foster placement. It is unknown
at this time if pool safety policies were reviewed or adhered to.
INVESTIGATION:
On August 4, 2021, at 11:30am I made an announced visit to the Muskegon County
Department of Health and Human Services (Muskegon DHHS) office.
2

On August 4, 2021, I interviewed MDHHS Licensing worker 1 at Muskegon DHHS.
MDHHS Licensing worker 1 stated that she became the assigned licensing worker in
April 2021. MDHHS Licensing worker 1 further stated that she has not met the foster
family yet and has not been to the home. Her only correspondence has been over
email. MDHHS Licensing worker 1 stated that the next annual for the foster family is
due early next year.
On August 4, 2021, I interviewed MDHHS Licensing Supervisor at Muskegon DHHS.
MDHHS Licensing Supervisor stated that MDHHS Licensing worker 3 completed the
renewal in January 2021 and at that time the pool was not operational due to being
wintertime. MDHHS Licensing Supervisor stated that MDHHS Licensing worker 3 did
not mention to her having any concerns regarding supervision by the foster parents
or the pool.
MDHHS Licensing worker 3 was not interviewed as he is on long term leave.
On August 4, 2021, I interviewed MDHHS Licensing worker 2 at Muskegon DHHS.
MDHHS Licensing worker 2 stated that she is assigned to the current special
evaluation involving the foster family. MDHHS Licensing worker 2 stated that she is
familiar with the foster family as she completed their renewal in 2019. MDHHS
Licensing worker 2 stated that there were no concerns at that time regarding
supervision and there were locks on all of the doors and alarms on the doors leading
to the back deck and pool area. Regarding the current complaint, MDHHS Licensing
worker 2 stated that when she conducted a home visit, she observed the door locks
and the door alarms. The alarm was activated when MDHHS Licensing worker 2
opened the sliding door that leads to the deck and pool area. MDHHS Licensing
worker 2 stated that she observed life jackets.
On August 4, 2021, I interviewed MDHHS FC worker at Muskegon DHHS. MDHHS
FC worker stated that she has been assigned to the case since October 2019.
MDHHS FC worker stated there were never any concerns regarding supervision or
the pool.
On August 10, 2021, I interviewed MDHHS worker 1 over the phone. MDHHS
worker 1 was concerned that the foster parents did not have anything protecting the
pool from the rest of the backyard (such as fence) but did not have any other
concerns.
I reviewed the following documents on August 3, 2021:
 Initial Foster/Adoption Home Evaluation (3130) for the licensed foster
placement dated July 20, 2017. The 3130 states the home had locks on all
the doors that lead to the pool as well as door alarms and a rescue pole.
 Foster Home Reevaluation (4004) dated January 29, 2021. The 4004 states
all doors leading to the pool in the backyard have locks on them as well as
door alarms and a rescue pole.
3

 The complaint and contacts on MISACWIS for investigation involving the
licensed foster placement. MDHHS worker 1 and MDHHS Licensing worker 2
viewed the home and observed that there was a wood dowel securing the
sliding door that leads to the pool. Another door on the side of the house that
can access the pool area had a lock. There was a door alarm on the sliding
door that went off when workers opened the door to observe the pool area.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.12321 Hazardous materials and firearm storage
(1) Federal standards for a foster family or group home
include specific safety requirements for weapons, pools,
hot tubs, and spas, as these pose a particular preventable
danger to children.
ANALYSIS: The agency is found in compliance as during review of
documentation in licensed foster home file and interviews the
foster home was aware and had door locks and alarms on doors
that access the pool area as well as a rescue equipment.
CONCLUSION: VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
I recommend no changes to the status of the license of this child placing agency.
___ _______8/13/2021__
Melinda Gubbins Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 19, 2021
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
